title: Researchers use superheated steam to sanitize dry food manufacturing plants - Food Safety News
summary: Researchers at Cornell University are developing a new tool to eliminate deadly pathogens in commercial dry food processing plants â€” superheated, dry steam. Superheated steam is heated beyond 212 degrees F to more than 250 degrees F, becomes invisible and acts like a hot gas, killing any pathogens and microbes, and leaves no moisture or condensation to harbor further pathogens. The research is relevant to milk powder and powdered infant formula, snack foods, spices, nuts, and nut butters, produce, as well as chocolate and other candies.
